Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Russell Howell (PI, Westmont College), Alan Noell (Oklahoma State University), and Paul Zorn (St. Olaf College) are organizing a one-week workshop (June 24 to 28, 2013, at Westmont College in Santa Barbara, CA). The workshop is producing a document that contains recommendations for revitalizing the content and teaching of a first course in complex analysis at the undergraduate level. The animating momentum behind the project is modeled after the successful reform movements in calculus and linear algebra. A follow-up contributed paper session and panel discussion is being planned for the 2014 Joint Mathematics Meetings in Baltimore, MD.

The fifteen workshop participants are researchers and educators trained in complex analysis, people with expertise in pedagogy, and people affiliated with scientific or industrial organizations who use complex analysis on a regular basis. One of the focal points of the workshop is looking at ways of enhancing and expanding applications of complex analysis that are usually presented to undergraduates. Other goals being pursued include crafting recommendations for technology and pedagogy, with special emphasis on identifying promising (or, better yet, tested) inquiry-based learning approaches to the subject of complex analysis at the undergraduate level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The subject of complex analysis deals with the calculus of numbers that can be represented as points on a two-dimensional grid. Despite its beauty and power, the subject has lost some of the prominence it once enjoyed in undergraduate mathematics, science, and engineering courses. Complex analysis evolved during the ninteenth century, and many of the problems it addresses can now be solved with computer algebra systems. Thus, for purely practical computational purposes much of the motivation for learning complex analysis has faded.

On the positive side, computer technology now offers valuable new ways of visualizing several topics in complex analysis. Further, there appears still to be strong support for undergraduate complex analysis, suitably re-envisioned, because of its uses in signal analysis and control/stability systems. At the theoretical level, complex analysis draws on and links important domains of classical mathematics.

Thanks to NSF support a group of 16 scholars covened at Westmont College, Santa Barbara, CA (June 23--27, 2014) to discuss ways of revitalizing complex analysis. After two days of presenting ideas three subgroups formed in accordance with the interest of the participants. The first was a "modules" group, which focused on specific new topics that might be used in an undergraduate class (either during lectures, or as assigned projects). The second was a "transitions" group, which created a syllabus for a new course that would at once bridge students to higher mathematics, and also introduce standard topics in complex analysis early (so that, when students took a complex analysis course, they could progress further). Finally, a "revisionist" group investigated ways to enliven the current practices for teaching the course. In some ways this approach sought outcomes that the first two groups pursued: carefully selected modules can certainly enhance a mathematics course, and effective technological and pedagogical techniques afford the opportunity to cover some standard material more quickly.

Thus, a main outcome of the Westmont Workshop was the production of three different curricula for consideration in the teaching of complex analysis. Another outcome was the contribution of papers at a "Revitalizing Complex Analysis" contributed paper session held at the 2015 Join Mathematics Meetings in San Antonio, Texas. Many scholars in addition to the workshop participants presented. The response was so positive that the single session was split into two separate sessions. A similar contributed paper session has been accepted by the Mathematical Association of America for the 2016 Joint Mathematics Meetings to be held in Seattle, Washington.

An unexpected outcome is the forthcoming theme issue dedicated to the revitalization project that will be produced by the journal PRIMUS (Problems, Resources, and Issues in Mathematics Undergraduate Studies). The Principal Investigator of this project was asked to be a guest editor for that issue as a result of the contributed paper sessions held at the San Antonio meetings. Paper submissions are due September 1, 2015.
